												One of the most enjoyable co-op experiences I've had. Great puzzles, beautiful art style, cute characters, good music. Get a whole lot of mileage out of a handful of simple gameplay mechanics. You'll find yourself screaming in frustration,  shouting and pumping your fist in triumph, erupting in cathartic laughter as it finally seems you and your friend will accomplish the intricate, difficult procedure you've spent so long figuring out and attempting, only to see your friend make a stupid mistake and ruin everything at the last second.The game only lets you communicate with your online parter by drawing blobby, imprecise lines onscreen. This could be seen as a drawback, but in fact it becomes its own meta-puzzle: how do I explain this detailed series of actions that will involve precise timing, without using any words? You come to develop a rudimentary syntax; you start saying yes and no by moving back and forth and jumping up and down, respectively, or you draw frantic scribbles on the screen to indicate frustration. It's so much more satisfying to solve puzzles this way; you really feel like you've accomplished something beyond the game itself. Of course there are also those infuriating moments when you give up trying to use the in-game language and resort to Steam chat, or even make a phone call and talk through it in real time. And then there are transcendent moments when you and your partner both know exactly what to do without attempting any communication at all. It's also great fun to be a jerk and push your partner over cliffs or into enemies. If I have only one criticism it's that if you're playing with more than one friend (say, one online and one IRL) there's no reliable way to keep track of which levels you've finished with each friend. Like, I beat the game with friend A while I was only a few levels in with friend B, and then I'd start up the game with friend B and some of the puzzles would start to seem mighty familiar, and I couldn't be sure if it was only because I'd already played them with friend A, or because I'd also already played them with friend B. You can reset ALL of your progress, which would have made it easier to kow where I was with friend B if I'd started with them AFTER beating the game with friend A, but I had two games going at the same time so deleting my progress with friend A would have deleted the friend B's progress as well, and it wouldn't have been fair to friend A, either, if we ever decided we wanted to go back and try to get all the crystals on certain levels without replaying all the others. The option for separate play "sessions" could have solved this (I always thought having three save slots in the Zelda games was overkill, but now I see the reasoning behind it). But, lengthy complaint notwithstanding, this is really a minor problem.I was lucky enough to get this in a double pack as part of a bundle, but It's definitely worth the full price.

Ibb & Obb		* 7/10No story. No settings. Just Puzzles. End of Review.No, seriously, how can a game like this be so nice? Really, there's no story because it wouldn't change that much, the setting is irrelevant it's more about the art itself. The only thing that matters in this game is cooperative work, and that's because this game is Cooperative only, either local or via servers.So, this is a sidescroll platform and you have to play with a friend as Ibb & Obb. All you have to do is run the two fellas along the world. A world split in half by the ground and you can switch side through occasional portals in order to get past dangers or obstacles. Obviously the other side has an inverted gravity and this is just one of the many little things that you will notice along your runs with your friend as there will be many more obstacles and situations that will require cooperation and teamwork, tight syncronization and creative solution as the more you'll progress through the levels, the more complicated and elaborated the situations will be.The artistic aspect of the game is so minimalistic, but colorful and polished, kind of childish but it's not that kind of dumb childish. It's something relaxing and maybe a bit nostalgic. The music isn't anything outstanding but it's a very nice and light musical accompaniment that will encourage that relax sensation you have while playing this game.I must admit that I kind of get angry when I get stuck with games both for difficulty or unsolvable puzzles, but with Ibb & Obb it just doesn't happen. I stand and wait, I try to figure a solution, a workaround, I discuss with my friend a possible way to pass through and if we just can't figure it out we'll just end our session to resume the next days (with success).+++PROs+++ GAMEPLAY. This is the only thing that matters: the game is very a very simple sidescrolling platform, where you and your friend help each other to get ahead of obstacles and dangers. That's all. And it's so simple that it's fun. VISUAL ART. As already mentioned this game is very neat, colorful and simple. It's not even 3d and I never felt the need for it to be. MUSIC. A very simple music accompaniment will set a relaxing atmosphere as you proceed the game. The music will never try to get in the way but still can be appreciated.---CONs--- NETCODE. There must be something seriously wrong with the game's netcode because when I play it in coop with my friend sometimes it works just fine, but most of the times it just lags like hell, and sometimes we see each other's character just walk forward until it meets an obstacle or death. The strangest thing is that these situations seems to happen mostly in areas with multiple enemies, and this led us to the point where it was impossible to play from our own places, so I had to grab my laptop and reach my friend to play and finish the game. Unfortunately it seems like no efforts were made for this well known bug. FINAL RIDDLE. The final enemy seems to have just one way to beat it and it relies excessively in timing to the point that we thought that our solution was wrong because simply impossible. Actually we had to do everything in perfect timing not wasting a single step and second. This is not the kind of solution I was expecting considering the rest of the game... LOADING. Well, to say it plainly It wasn't much intuitive to load my progress the very first time, as you always begin your game and you should choose the platforms to jump on to load a map. Problem is: there's nothing written to recognize the map or at least its number, there's just the number of collected gems. MENU SETTINGS. Well, I can understand the fact that there's not much to set, specially for graphics, but maybe it would be useful at the very least the audio levels. Nothing really bad or necessary, but it might be useful.I played this game on these machines:Laptop Lenovo Z50Intel Core i5-4210U8Gb RAM DDR3GeForce 840MIntel HD Graphics 4400Windows 10 Home x64Intel Core i7-497016Gb RAM DDR3GeForce GTX 660Windows 10 Professional x64

Posted: November 15, 2015
												This game is cute, has great music and challenging puzzles. And you play it in cooperation with a buddy. What's not to like?The puzzles are challenging not only in regard to their solution. They often require both players to perfectly execute several steps in a row, with very little room for error. This can mean that you have already figured out the solution and make it halfway there but then you misstep: Start over. Then, your friend is too fast: Start over. Then, you jump a little too early:  Start over. Then, your friend hits an enemy: You know the drill. Solving a puzzle can get quite tedious.Another issue is savegames: One level took us up to an hour (in the later stages), depending both of how well we could crack the puzzle logic and execute the steps. During that, the game saved our progress just fine; if we failed a puzzle, we'd only be back at its beginning. But whenever we had to quit before finishing the level (or had a desync or just didn't feel like trying the same puzzle for the umpteenth time), the next time, we'd have to restart the whole level from the beginning.Finally, playing it with a friend across the ocean, we found that in-game voice chat was delayed by a few seconds. Maybe it doesn't happen with less of a distance between you and your co-player. For us, it didn't help, what with some puzzles needing near-perfect timing. Towards the end, we thought about using an external solution like Raidcall, but it never came to that.Overall, the game can get quite frustrating.Before this, we played Portal 2, which did a better job of e.g. the savegame issue by having many smaller levels, so if you had to quit at some point, you wouldn't have to replay as much as in this game. And there, when you already knew the steps leading up to where you'd left off, they were usually pretty easy to reproduce. If you're looking for a fun coop puzzler, I'd rather recommend Portal 2.

												I had never heard of this game, but I stumbled across it while searching for online co-op games to play with a friend.  I don't ordinarily write reviews, but I like this game so much that I wanted to spread the word.The basics: In Ibb & Obb, you are in a world that has an unusual form of gravity.  If you look at the screenshots, you can see that there is a line that roughly divides the playfield into a top and bottom.  When you are above this line, gravity works how you would expect.  When you are below it, you "fall" up, towards the line.  (In other words, you're always attracted to the line.)  You can only switch sides at the various gates in the level (the particle-y lines in the pictures).  ORdinarily these gates are white, but some gates are red or green.  Anyone can go through a white gate, but only the character that matches the color of the gate can pass through the red and green ones.The challenge comes from cooperating with your partner to solve the puzzles.  This often requires making clever use of your momentum when switching from one side to the other.  As you can see in the video, enemies can be killed on one side of the line, but the player on the other side has to collect the gems.What I like:This game is gorgeous.  I find the colors to be very satisfying, and I find the overall art style to be very pleasant.  Obviously not everyone may agree, but I want to really commend the developers for making such a stylish game.Same thing for the music.  Pretty much as soon as the game started, I thought, "Wow, this music is great."  I never really stopped thinking that.The gameplay is also fun.  The puzzles start off fairly simply to introduce you to the mechanics, then start to become a little trickier.  This is especially true once you realize that there are optional gems floating around in some places - getting these requires more thought than simply figuring out how to beat the level.  So far, the puzzles are hard enough that you feel satisfied when you beat them, but not so hard that you ever get frustrated.I'd also like to mention the way this game is packaged.  You can buy a single copy, and it would be a fair price, but for slightly more money you can buy a double pack and gift a copy to a friend.  This game is definitely meant to be played with a friend, and the devs make it very easy to do that by so strongly incentivizing the double pack.What I don't like:Honestly, I don't have any complaints so far.  I've really been enjoying this game.What I don't know:I'm not sure how long the game is.  That information might be available, but I haven't really checked.  Given how reasonably priced the game is, especially with a double pack, I don't feel like it would have to be super long for me to get my money's worth.  I'll update this if I end up beating it in 15 minutes the next time I play, but I haven't even seen all the areas highlighted in the screenshots, so I don't expect that to happen.Conclusion:I highly recommend this game.  It's beautiful, fun, and clever.  I only wish that I'd heard about it sooner!

Posted: January 1, 2015
												Are you looking for another fun puzzle game? As a fan of the genre myself, I can say I look often. This game stood out for it's art style, co-op, and simplicity.When it comes to puzzle platformers, ibb & obb uses a recently popular mind-bending alteration on physics. Many of its peer platformers have also used dual or mirrored characters, but not quite in this same way. In those, you the player are able to control both. Here, each character must fend for himself, but also cooperate to succeed. It has taken cues from the co-op element of Portal, but is still self-contained.While I typically don't enjoy platformers in the genre, this was an exception. Simplicity is key, and the developers executed it very well. It doesn't remain the same throughout, and there is clear progression in the art, but it's always minimal, clean, and fresh. The smooth dream-like artistry behind it, including the music, is excellent and I applaud it.There is hardly any story, which is fine with this game, and what exists is only shown visually, and you are up to interpret it. It's not as integral, but makes for a neat dynamic if you think about it. I think this part could be developed further. While it's clean, and I like that, it's not overly progressed. It appears, and then goes nowhere. Because of this, it doesn't stick with you long after you play. It's good and lovely mental and cooperative exercise, but not much more.The puzzle difficulty is variable, and you can choose to pursue more challenging ones that don't hinder you from the main drive. Co-op makes this a lot of fun, as you decipher these physics traps together. It's a good communication and team-building exercise also. It certainly delivers on mental puzzlers, and if you enjoy them, I recommend it to you.

Posted: January 6, 2015
												ibb & obb might be the most adorable game I've ever seen.Psychedelic colors swirl around the screen, weird geometric characters dance about, parties are thrown for no reason whatsoever; it's just so 'effing cute and I wanted so much to fall in love with it. But playing ibb & obb is like petting a dog and having it bite your fingers off. It's cuteness is equally matched if not exceeded by its degree of frustrating, nonsensical design decisions, to where my head began to hurt so much I'm not sure how I ever managed to complete the trek through hell that was somehow hiding below the delightful exterior.Just to be entirely clear, ibb & obb is coop only, meaning you better have a friend ready and willing to brave its horrors with you before you even press start. And to this point there are some pretty cool ideas buried here, which force you to play cooperatively and make clever use of its main gravity inverting hook. There are two sides to every level, with each flipping your character over like you've cut a hole straight through to the other side of the world and gravity hasn't yet realized.Using both characters in tandem is almost always required to allow both to progress, be it providing a step up onto a ledge or using momentum to carry each other through. It's a fantastic hook but its implementation here is unbelievably hamstrung and convoluted. The camera that has to contend with two characters often going in opposite directions bears much of the blame, often obscuring parts of the environment or even your character entirely as you fight against it to keep moving as it holds you back. The pretty environments come at the const of making levels difficult to even comprehend, often blending so well with platforms or bubbles I needed to float in that I often had no idea they were something I needed to interact with.Puzzle designs, while on occasion genuinely brilliant, are often constructed such a ridiculous manner that numerous times throughout the game I thought we were breaking the game finding their solutions. So many moments are needlessly tedious and absurdly challenging, forcing literal split-second timing which its floaty, imprecise controls make cumbersome at the best of times and a living nightmare at its worst. Each new mechanic introduced only seems to worsen the already overburdened experience, leaving exasperated and fatigued before I was even halfway through. The abundance of network lag (which from what I've gathered is by no means an isolated issue) made parts of the game nearly impassible, as if the game was at last telling me to give up as my character ran wildly around at his own inclination.The dissonance between ibb & obb's truly marvelous artwork and mellow soundtrack and it's reprehensible gameplay is probably one of the most shocking I've ever experienced. It's bewildering and depressing, and I'm still finding it hard to fathom how miserable an experience it was to play when it all seemed so wonderful from the outside.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

Posted: February 16, 2015
												I wish I could recommend this game, but there are issues which cannot be ignored. I can't in good conscience say that someone should get this game until they're fixed. I will admit though that some of these issues are due to being disabled, which will result in some hate (because as we know the only people who like disabled people are disabled people), but I need to talk about this.Screen ZoomingI have poor sight, so when the screen suddenly zooms way out I find it easy to lose track of my character, or I'll get vertigo and my precision will be off. In a game with online multiplayer, this kind of zooming is unnecessary and only serves to irritate the player. An online game should use a set zoom (with the zoom level in the options). A pointer could point the position of the other character. This wouldn't really require much extra code as there's a pointer that tracks the other player in-game right now (if one player goes too high off screen, it'll show the position of the player lower down), which makes this even more baffling.If this were fixed for online games, it would make the experience much more enjoyable. As it is, the constant stretching and shrinking, stretching and shrinking, stretching and shrinking makes me feel nauseous. I understand that a temporary zoom to show what you need to do may sometimes be necessary, but just trigger that then have the zoom go away. Or even give the player a 'zoom out' toggle key which they can use whenever they want.But making it zoom and zip around like mad makes it feel like a Ubisoft game where the controls are so often stolen away. This would be a much, much, much more playable experience if this was fixed.CollectiblesI have an anxiety disorder. Whenever I fail to get collectibles, I feel like I've failed my co-op partner. For some people, this is exciting, exhilarating, and fun. For me, it results in my heart racing, pounding, and feeling faint and panicky. That sense of panic will grow and my hands will start shaking. Combine this with the above issue and I find ibb & obb (especially on the harder levels) a genuinely unpleasant play experience.This could be fixed by having an option so that they don't decay. I know that there are some nutty, obsessive cheevo-hunters out there who're hardcore or no-core, so just disabled the Steam achievements tied in with collectibles if the co-op partners agree to turn on the option to stop the collectibles from decaying. That way, it's an option, which doesn't hurt anyone, and the hardcore cheevo-hunters can have their hadcore cheevo-hunting.As it is, though, the decay makes this a stressful experience. Otherwise, it would be a pleasant, enjoyable, serene, cerebral experience. It would be more like Portal 2, then. I love Portal 2, standing around and trying to figure out a test chamber without the immediate pressure of ermahgerd I stepped on a thing, now the collectibles are going to decay, whatever will I do? So I won't be playing much more ibb & obb due to this.Of course, this means that the collectibles will stick around if you die, too. I know, gosh, such a carebear. But I'm an old fart with disabilities, I'm not 15 any more. We can't all be perfect.It just really, really frustrates me because I could see the potential of this as a serene puzzler, it could be in my top ten with the likes of Myst and Portal, but this silly, ridiculous design decision to cause stress and anxiety for no good reason just does so, so much to ruin the game. And it does ruin the game. And it is stupid. And it does stop it from reaching its potential. I just want to shake some sense into the developers, because it could be so much more. It's so close to being an epic cult classic for the ages.Game SyncingThis may not be fixable, but it's a very serious issue. It also triggers my panic in various ways.Way 1:"You didn't get the collectibles.""Yes. I did. I really did.""No, you didn't. I saw them explode all over the place and you didn't even bother with them.""But ... I caught the ball before it exploded.""Not on my end.""I did on my end, honest! I caught it!""Have you seen me ignoring collectibles?""Yeah, but I didn't want to say...""Welp, that's a bug."Way 2:"You need to get rid of this porcupine.""I did. I did that a while ago, and the collectibles popped out. I saw you get some of them.""...none of this happened.""I think it's bugging again. Here, let me come back. Is this where the porcupine is?""Yes.""It can't harm me...""Look, it'll kill me.""Well damn. How do we fix this?""Keep trying until it works, I guess?"It took me and one co-op partner some time to figure out that there were syncing errors. I'm very hesitant to play it with any of my other friends as we'd have to go through this again and again, with each new person playing. This isn't my idea of a fun time. The game should at least mention that these bugs can occur when booting the game if they can't be fixed. It causes a lot of friction between co-op partners.ConclusionThis very flawed gem has the potential to become the next Portal 2, one of the best co-op puzzle experiences on Steam, perhaps even the best co-op experience on Steam. But the first of these two issues need to be fixed, the latter should be fixed, but if extenuating circumstances don't allow it, at least warn co-op partners that it can happen to alleviate potential stress.This could be good. Could be. As it is, it makes me a bag of stress with shaky hands. I can't help but dislike it for that. I don't want too. I want to like it. But the way I feel about it means that I can't recommend it.It's great if you have perfect sight, motor control, and no anxiety. It's great if you can put up with the game sync issues without getting stressed. In that case? I recommend it without reservation, go ahead, it's the most fun you can have with co-op puzzling outside of Portal 2. But for anyone whom these may be an issue for? No.No. I just can't recommend this. I want to, but I can't. Please fix these issues so that I can recommend ibb & obb. I really, really want to.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Ibb & Obb is a gravity-based puzzle-platformer.Which isn't to say you manually adjust gravity, as with some games, but that the entire game is composed of things like 'slow fall bubbles', trampolines, looped falling (where you drop from the sky after falling off the bottom of the screen), and reverse-gravity wells.Despite fairly simple concepts, the puzzles quickly move from charming and cute and simple, to demanding and clever.Unlike twitch/reflex platformers, once you actually figure out the trick to a puzzle, you're good to move on, which makes this a game more about testing your wit, than your reflexes- though timing is certainly important, as well.Ibb & Obb is one of the best co-op experiences I've had in a while, and I can certainly recommend it-Though there's some things I unfortunately have to point out.||PROS||* Co-op only play guarantees an experience built with co-op in mind at all facets. * Puzzles are based around clever reuses of a small set of objects, presented in more and more complex ways, thus creating a steadily progressing experience where you build off what you've learned from your previous successes, rather than having to start each puzzle from scratch.* Ibb & Obb (the two player-controlled characters in the game) are different sizes. This can have some interesting effects on gameplay, and is actually crucial to later puzzles. It's a nice twist that keeps each co-op partner feeling distinct in their roles. Similarly, the use of color-coded barriers limits which character can progress at points, creating interesting 'how do we both progress' puzzles.* Looped falling can be surprisingly hilarious* You can 'bend the system' by attempting crazy mid-air combos, such as trying to jump off your partner as they loop-fall. This can sometimes provide alternative ways to solve puzzles, for players that enjoy precision-reflex approaches over puzzle approaches. But really, it'll take quite a few attempts to do- though it's quite satisfying when you manage it.* Charming atmosphere, and the most adorable little interactables- that you can actually push into enemies to cause the enemies to change course, or bounce onto enemy killing buttons, or just kick around like soccer balls, sometimes to absolutely hilarious effect. Great little tidbit for more creative puzzle solving, and just general palate cleansing.* The ability to aim for a perfect score, by gathering all the enemy-kill score drops, for the more dedicated completionists.||NEUTRAL||* Secret stages are brutal and difficult to intuit, and may be best skipped by all but the most dedicated mental gymnasts. * This game gets hard. It looks like it's designed for kids, but most kids won't have the patience to complete this kid of game [and if you know one that does, give them a cookie, they're awesome].  This is definitely a game for the patient and the people who really like working through problems until they understand them. If you're into really puzzle-oriented games, enjoy teamwork, and physics manipulation, you're going to probably like this game. If your expectations run toward something more- or less- active in involvement, you may not.* Similarly, puzzles will require several attempts to figure out, and at the time we played, all the walkthroughs were for the console version (which has different stages, see Cons below). Plus side, every time we got stuck and needed an assist, it was us overthinking a puzzle, so there's that. :) Still, patience is a virtue- and one you may need to rely on for this game.Then again, you'll still die less, hate yourself less, and feel far less frustrated than with twitch/reflex platformers, so there's that~* Relatively short. 6 to 7 hours without the last level (see Cons), but that's mostly due to repetition in figuring out each puzzle. The core content is probably 2-3 hours in length, assuming a run-through where you know what you're doing. (Secret levels will of course extend this time a bit further, if you choose to do them.)||CONS||* The last level is broken on the PC port- or rather, several levels got reimagined for the PC port (which is kinda cool) but the reimagining of the last level caused it to be incompletable (which is kinda not cool). The game plays fine up to that point, so if you're able to view the end of the game being a level sooner, you'll be fine- If you're a completionist, this screw-up may drive you up a wall.Especially with given how demanding the prior level was- you can only imagine how awesome this final level could have been..* No mid-level save points, so you're forced to complete a stage to make progression in it.[Each puzzle section within a stage does have its own respawn point, however.]Plus side, once you know the puzzles, you can breeze through if you need to leave and restart- still, this feels like an unfortunate and arbitrary exclusion.* Likewise, this game seems to have low replay value, given that non-campaign-level challenges (ie, secret levels) are all extreme in challenge, and all puzzles in the game are fairly easy to complete once you know how to do them.This is a bit of a difficult game to describe, but if you like undertaking a mental challenge with a partner, and neither of you are the type to get agitated when you get stuck, then it's a fantastic game I recommend highly.As always with co-operation games of this nature, if either person gets easily stressed, expect eventual argument and rage-quitting.Despite that phrasing, it's not an especially frustrating game (in MY opinion), since everything CAN be figured out through rethinking and continously retesting your approach to a puzzle.Still, it's a bit niche in its challenge, a bit curious in how certain things (like secret levels) are approached, and, of course, the last level cannot be played.So..I tentatively give it a 4/5. Seriously, if it sounds at all good to you, give it a shot- and if it sounds at all not good to you, don't. ~.^

												I usually don't bother leaving games a review at all, let alone a negative one......and, it pains me to leave this game a negative review, because it aims to be something very rare (and something I much desire) in the video game marketplace: an age-neutral co-op game. All the other coop games on the marketplace are shooters with blood and guts and the disemboweled souls of little puppies flying everywhere. I was hoping that the game would be something fun to play with young folk. It was excellent until we reached the little black spikeballs of death that chase you. Despite all our combined inginuity and (not too terrible) platforming skills, we could not progress past a certain scene with spiky deathballs that chase you. Was there a difficulty setting we could turn down? Nope. Were there cheat codes we could use to experience the rest of the game? Nope. Could we just "git gud"? I suppose,  but the goal wasn't to play an intense, twitch-based, control-heavy platformer.. it was to have fun with a friend, and also to solve some cool two-player puzzles (like the gameplay trailer shows.)The little black monster also neatly brought into focus the game's other failings: the controls are unpleaseantly slippery, which exascerbates the precision needed to engage the puzzles and platforming elements, especially perching on your friend's head. Perching on your friend's head is an element needed to solve many puzzles, but for such a pivotal gameplay element, it relatively difficult to achieve. We always needed two or three tries to accomplish something central.All-in-all, from what I've seen, the concept is good, and the art is fairly cool, and the mood is cheerful, but the execution was a fail, because the execution kept us from experiencing the rest of the game. I wish I could reccomend this--I really do.

												So, I forget where I first read about this game. Probably somewhere in the vijagame jouranlisms.  I really liked the visual aesthetic and the idea of a puzzle platformer built not just with co-op in mind, but built entirely around co-op as a necessary central mechanic.  I ended up playing the first level and a half solo just to get a feel for the game, and came away with the impression that it was going to be a cute, clever, but ultimately soft experience.That was quite some time ago.  Recently got into it seriously with a friend, and damn, my initial impression was proven wrong.  This game is certainly cute but it is anything but soft.  ibb & obb will challenge your brain meat.  The semi-hidden bonus stages especially; they gave us several excellent opporutnities to flex our brain muscle and were always very satisfying to solve.  Considering all your character can do is move and jump, it's amazing the depth of puzzles they're able to create with concepts like maintaining or building momentum or manipulating which direction gravity pulls your character.The only basic mechanic you have other than moving and jumping is a little colorful bubble trail thing you can create with either the mouse or the right stick, if you're using a controller.  It's the only communication tool you have in-game, and I was impressed with how much information we were able to convey to each other using this simple, visual medium.  Of course sometimes we had to open a chat window to talk deeper strategy, but still it's an elegant solution for the issue of communication between players that fits in with the game's minimalist approach to it's mechanics and aesthetic.I only have a couple negative points to share. The game starts out slow as you learn the mechanics and builds up the complexity on a pretty satisfying curve, but there are a couple challenges that boil down to basically challenges to your manual dexterity rather than your abilty to problem solve, and those are never as satsifying.  Secondly, we played online and towards the end experienced some pretty bad lag, which the game was not always good at mitigating.  We ended up with some weird lag artifacts like random enemies spawning in locations they shouldn't that only damaged one of the two players, or multiple copies of either ibb or obb respawning at once, or just really long wait times to respawn after death. Generally play was smooth and honestly you have to expect some problems when you play online over a crappy connection, but when the lag got particularly bad, the game had more trouble with it than I was expecting.It's a relatively short game but there's so few games out there that are anything like it, and those few hours are densely packed.  ibb & obb is pure gameplay; there's no text or any exposition of any kind anywhere in the game. A Challenging Co-op ExperienceIbb and Obb is a cooperative game meant to be played with a partner. It's a 2D platformer in which you have to complete puzzles together in order to progress. Each person plays as one of the titular characters, and your goal is to complete levels by helping each other get past obstacles through various means.The game design is simplistic, but elegant. The world is divided into two parts, above and below the ground, and gravity is inverted while you are below, meaning that you will "fall" upwards. The game is simple enough that the lack of a tutorial doesn't really matter; players can intuitively figure out how things work.My main gripe with this game is how hard it can be for someone who's not used to playing video games. Although the controls are easy enough for just about anyone to grasp, some of the puzzles can be extremely difficult to complete. My partner and I got stuck on an early level because one of the puzzles required her to complete a series of actions precisely, with very little time to spare. She couldn't do it, so I had to do that part for her in order to finish that level.Currently, we're at a point which requires too much coordination, and we both agreed that it would be next to impossible for us to get through together. Thus, we've simply stopped playing the game, which is sad, considering how much fun we've had playing so far, despite certain bouts of frustration.Another annoyance is that there is no in-game option to switch characters. Your character is determined based on whether you created or joined a game; if you start a game, you will play as Ibb, the green character, whereas if you are joining a game, you will play as Obb, the red one. I feel like the inability to switch characters is such a big oversight, because depending on which one you play, you will have different obstacles to overcome, and some of them are much more difficult, in my opinion.In summary, this is a fun little two-player game that is very easy to pick up. It's an especially great game for couples in long distance relationships, as you may sometimes find yourselves yelling at each other, which often leads to laughter. However, I would not recommend this game to those without any prior video game experience. Both players need to have good coordination together to be able to make it further into this game. Overall, this game can be challenging, but it is certainly enjoyable.

Posted: November 28, 2015
												Very few games do co-op right. Some have little to no co-op interaction, and the players might as well be playing alone. Some have "shared lives" where the less experienced player feels like they're dragging down the team. Ibb & Obb has the best co-op mechanics of the many, many cooperative games I've played.Ibb & Obb is a puzzle platformer. Both players are needed to solve every puzzle, meaning a player is never left out or dragged behind. Sometimes the puzzles require that the players fill specific roles--Ibb. the green guy, is allowed through green portals and Obb, the red guy, is allowed through red portals. The developers cleverly alternate the use of these portals to ensure that no one player always takes the active role in each puzzle.My sole criticism is that Ibb & Obb doesn't have in-game communcation to match the intricacy of its puzzles. Players can only draw colored lines in the air, but they are fairly short and fade quickly. This problem disappears if you're playing couch co-op or are using a mic.The puzzles are excellent and make clever use of teamwork and physics.The graphics and visuals are very pleasing.The soundtrack is amazing and certainly worth owning as well.Ibb & Obb is among the best of the indie, co-op, puzzle-platform, and artsy genres. If you've got a co-op buddy, this game is definitely worth your time.

												One of the best Co-Op puzzle games I think I've played in a long time. Many games have come out for two (or more) players to try to solve puzzles together, but fall into one of a few traps: -One player too easily can take over, directing the other player(s) to the solution or simply doing it all themself, while waiting for the others to catch up, or making the others feel the puzzle is being spoiled for them.-The game forces each player into a specialized role which means they each have a specific job to do, and whoever is better/faster at the game is left waiting for others to figure things out. (Which makes it feel like everyone is playing their own solo game together, but separately.)-The game tries to force individual problem solving by limiting or not giving any ways for the players to communicate.Ibb & Obb does a good job of not falling into any of these traps through thoughtful puzzles and unique style and gameplay.The gameplay and style are truly unique, both in terms of design and visuals/music. A very lovely game that is challenging without being too hard, and has plenty of content without being a grind nor too short.

												This is a beautiful, well-crafted game.The controls and game-mechanics are introduced organically through gameplay, without so much as a word of instruction, which is definitely no easy feat and probably the thing I think is most amazing about this game.The puzzles are sufficiently difficult that when you finally get that light-bulb moment, the rush cannot be topped, but equally they're not unfair or excessively punishing.The music, sound design and art style are minimalistic and stylish, but neverthless manage to convey a lot of emotion about how you should feel in a given level.Working together with your friend to solve the puzzles often involves "signing" - when you move your mouse it draws a line in your character's colour across the screen where the cursor is, that the other player can see. This is a simple yet powerful system for letting your partner know what you're thinking and what you'd like them to do. However, sometimes its just a tiny bit too simplistic and a built-in text or voice chat would have been nice, even if its only used occassionally to express the more complex plans.If I had to name a bad point, its that the game is essentially multiplayer-only. It is possible to play the game on your own, by controlling both ibb & obb yourself, but this quickly becomes an impossible multitasking demand. Its an unfair gripe though, because the game's whole point is about working together with a friend to solve the puzzles: don't buy if you don't have a friend to play with, otherwise, I can't recommend this game enough.
